elements.content: A novel infinite 2D silver(I) phthalate coordination polymer (CP), {CH3CN⊂[Ag2(pta)]4·CH3CN} n , (1, H2pta = phthalic acid) was synthesized and characterized. The flowerpot-shaped cavity in the sheet accommodates a linear acetonitrile molecule through quadruplex Ag···Nacetonitrile interaction. Using H2O as a solvent in the same preparative procedure, another silver(I) phthalate CP 2, {[Ag2(pta)(H2O)]} n , was isolated. Complex 2 is also a 2D sheet but does not include any solvent-occupied cavity. A comparative experiment shows that the acetonitrile acts as a template for the sheet formation. Moreover, the TGA and photoluminescence spectra of 1 and 2 were discussed.
elements.clean_text: A novel infinite 2D silver(I) phthalate coordination polymer (CP), {CH3CN⊂[Ag2(pta)]4⋅CH3CN} n , (1, H2pta = phthalic acid) was synthesized and characterized. The flowerpot-shaped cavity in the sheet accommodates a linear acetonitrile molecule through quadruplex Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile interaction. Using H2O as a solvent in the same preparative procedure, another silver(I) phthalate CP 2, {[Ag2(pta)(H2O)]} n , was isolated. Complex 2 is also a 2D sheet but does not include any solvent-occupied cavity. A comparative experiment shows that the acetonitrile acts as a template for the sheet formation. Moreover, the TGA and photoluminescence spectra of 1 and 2 were discussed.

elements.content: A novel infinite 2D silver(I) phthalate coordination polymer was synthesized and characterized. The acetonitrile molecule acts as a template for the sheet formation and interacts with the flowerpot-shaped cavity through quadruplex Ag···Nacetonitrile interaction.
elements.clean_text: A novel infinite 2D silver(I) phthalate coordination polymer was synthesized and characterized. The acetonitrile molecule acts as a template for the sheet formation and interacts with the flowerpot-shaped cavity through quadruplex Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile interaction.

elements.content: The self-assembly of metal-containing cages, macrocycles, and coordination polymers (CPs) with an interior cavity has drawn tremendous attention due to enormous structural diversity and their promising applications in molecular/ionic recognition, gas sorption/separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and sensors. The template methodology is a predominated route to achieve assembly of such compounds. The directing effect of templating agents generally originates from their noncovalent interactions with the host, including van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic forces, electrostatic effects, and/or π···π stacking, which not only enable the synthesis of molecules in a more rational and efficient manner but also aid in the preparation of assemblies that possess novel topologies, such as helicates, catenanes, rotaxanes, and Borromean rings. On the contrary to the widely-used anionic template, neutral species templates have been very little exploited in this field. As a ubiquitous solvent in the laboratory and industry, the linear acetonitrile molecule acting as a templating agent in synthetic chemistry was much less documented, which is probably a result of its poor ability to form noncovalent interactions with the host. In the course of our recent studies on Ag(I) CPs, we unrevealed an acetonitrile-templated infinite sheet CP, {CH3CN⊂[Ag2(pta)]4·CH3CN} n (1, H2pta = phthalic acid; Scheme ), in which acetonitrile molecules were embedded in the flowerpot-shaped cavities through quadruplex Ag···Nacetonitrile interactions.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of metal-containing cages, macrocycles, and coordination polymers (CPs) with an interior cavity has drawn tremendous attention due to enormous structural diversity and their promising applications in molecular/ionic recognition, gas sorption/separation, catalysis, drug delivery, and sensors. The template methodology is a predominated route to achieve assembly of such compounds. The directing effect of templating agents generally originates from their noncovalent interactions with the host, including van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic forces, electrostatic effects, and/or π⋅⋅⋅π stacking, which not only enable the synthesis of molecules in a more rational and efficient manner but also aid in the preparation of assemblies that possess novel topologies, such as helicates, catenanes, rotaxanes, and Borromean rings. On the contrary to the widely-used anionic template, neutral species templates have been very little exploited in this field. As a ubiquitous solvent in the laboratory and industry, the linear acetonitrile molecule acting as a templating agent in synthetic chemistry was much less documented, which is probably a result of its poor ability to form noncovalent interactions with the host. In the course of our recent studies on Ag(I) CPs, we unrevealed an acetonitrile-templated infinite sheet CP, {CH3CN⊂[Ag2(pta)]4⋅CH3CN} n  (1, H2pta = phthalic acid; Scheme ), in which acetonitrile molecules were embedded in the flowerpot-shaped cavities through quadruplex Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile interactions.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Coordination Modes of the pta Ligand (a) in Complex <bold>1</bold> and (b) in Complex <bold>2</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr5" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2010-01562p_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination Modes of the pta Ligand (a) in Complex 1 and (b) in Complex 2

elements.content: Colorless plate crystals of complex 1 were readily synthesized via reaction of Ag2O and H2pta (molar ratio =1:1) in acetonitrile under ultrasonic conditions (see ). The phase purity of 1 is sustained by its powder X-ray diffraction pattern, which is consistent with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S1 in the ). The characteristic IR bands () in ∼1560 and ∼1400 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the deprotonated carboxyl group, respectively. The difference in the IR frequencies of the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations is consistent with the bridging coordination mode of the carboxylate in both complexes. These results are well in agreement with the crystal structure of 1.
elements.clean_text: Colorless plate crystals of complex 1 were readily synthesized via reaction of Ag2O and H2pta (molar ratio =1:1) in acetonitrile under ultrasonic conditions (see ). The phase purity of 1 is sustained by its powder X-ray diffraction pattern, which is consistent with that simulated on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S1 in the ). The characteristic IR bands () in ~1560 and ~1400 cm-1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the deprotonated carboxyl group, respectively. The difference in the IR frequencies of the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations is consistent with the bridging coordination mode of the carboxylate in both complexes. These results are well in agreement with the crystal structure of 1.

elements.content: The X-ray structure analysis of crystalline 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the P4/nnc space group and there are two crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions, one pta, and two acetonitrile molecules in the asymmetric unit. Analysis of the local symmetry shows that both acetonitrile molecules reside on the crystallographic 4-fold axis (site occupancy factor (SOF) = 1/4), which also passes through the center of the square cavity. As shown in Figure a, the Ag1 is located in a slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometry and coordinated by five O atoms from four different pta ligands. The distortion of the square-pyramidal geometry can be indicated by the calculated value of the τ5 parameter introduced by Addison to describe the geometry of a five-coordinate metal system, which is 0.024 for Ag1 (for the ideal square-pyramidal geometry, τ5 = 0). The Ag2 lies in a T-shaped geometry completed by three O atoms from three different pta ligands in which the maximum O−Ag−O bond angle is 163.69(11)°. The Ag−O bond distances observed in 1 fall in the range 2.204(3)−2.689(4) Å and agree with those found in related systems. The pta ligand adopts a μ7-η3:η2:η2:η1 coordination mode to link the Ag(I) ions into a 2D sheet structure along the ab plane. Although μ5-η1:η1:η2:η1 and μ6-η2:η2:η2:η1 coordination modes have been presented in [Ag4(pta)2(CH3COOH)] n , the μ7-η3:η2:η2:η1-pta is still unknown in the Ag−pta complex. Moreover, diverse Ag···Ag interactions exit in this sheet (Ag1···Ag2ii = 2.8082(5), Ag1···Ag1vi = 3.4275(5), Ag2···Ag2v = 3.4354(5) Å) which contribute to the stability of the 2D sheet. (Symmetry codes: (ii) x − 1/2, −y + 2, −z + 1/2; (v) −y + 5/2, x, z; (vi) −y + 2, −x + 2, −z + 1/2.)
elements.clean_text: The X-ray structure analysis of crystalline 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the P4/nnc space group and there are two crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions, one pta, and two acetonitrile molecules in the asymmetric unit. Analysis of the local symmetry shows that both acetonitrile molecules reside on the crystallographic 4-fold axis (site occupancy factor (SOF) = 1/4), which also passes through the center of the square cavity. As shown in Figure a, the Ag1 is located in a slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometry and coordinated by five O atoms from four different pta ligands. The distortion of the square-pyramidal geometry can be indicated by the calculated value of the τ5 parameter introduced by Addison to describe the geometry of a five-coordinate metal system, which is 0.024 for Ag1 (for the ideal square-pyramidal geometry, τ5 = 0). The Ag2 lies in a T-shaped geometry completed by three O atoms from three different pta ligands in which the maximum O-Ag-O bond angle is 163.69(11)°. The Ag-O bond distances observed in 1 fall in the range 2.204(3)-2.689(4) Å and agree with those found in related systems. The pta ligand adopts a μ7-η3:η2:η2:η1 coordination mode to link the Ag(I) ions into a 2D sheet structure along the ab plane. Although μ5-η1:η1:η2:η1 and μ6-η2:η2:η2:η1 coordination modes have been presented in [Ag4(pta)2(CH3COOH)] n , the μ7-η3:η2:η2:η1-pta is still unknown in the Ag-pta complex. Moreover, diverse Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions exit in this sheet (Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag2ii = 2.8082(5), Ag1⋅⋅⋅Ag1vi = 3.4275(5), Ag2⋅⋅⋅Ag2v = 3.4354(5) Å) which contribute to the stability of the 2D sheet. (Symmetry codes: (ii) x - 1/2, -y + 2, -z + 1/2; (v) -y + 5/2, x, z; (vi) -y + 2, -x + 2, -z + 1/2.)

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Ag centers in 1 with the thermal ellipsoids at the 30% probability level. The CH3CN molecules were removed for clarity. (b) View of the 2D sheet structure. The CH3CN molecules were shown with the space filling mode. (Symmetry codes: (i) −y + 3/2, x, z; (ii) x − 1/2, −y + 2, −z + 1/2; (iii) y, −x + 5/2, z; (iv) x + 1/2, −y + 2, −z + 1/2; (v) −y + 5/2, x, z.)
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environments of Ag centers in 1 with the thermal ellipsoids at the 30% probability level. The CH3CN molecules were removed for clarity. (b) View of the 2D sheet structure. The CH3CN molecules were shown with the space filling mode. (Symmetry codes: (i) -y + 3/2, x, z; (ii) x - 1/2, -y + 2, -z + 1/2; (iii) y, -x + 5/2, z; (iv) x + 1/2, -y + 2, -z + 1/2; (v) -y + 5/2, x, z.)

elements.content: The most fascinating feature of 1 is the presence of a square cavity which is comprised of four bulging phenyl rings as wall, four inverse-arranged phenyl rings as supports, and four Ag2 ions as bottom. The overall shape of this cavity is reminiscent of a flowerpot where one of two acetonitrile molecules is suspended and interacts with four symmetry-related basal Ag2 ions (Figure a and b). The acetonitrile N atom points downward toward the center of the bottom, consistent with the formation of a Ag···Nacetonitrile interaction. The Ag2···N1 distance is 2.824(6) Å, which is a little longer but still falls in the secondary bonding range (the sum of van der Waals radii of Ag and N is 3.27 Å) and is comparable to other reported Ag···acetonitrile weak coordination interactions. The entrapped acetonitrile molecules in the holes of the 2D sheet are alternately arranged as shown in Figure b. Another acetonitrile molecule just acts as guest to occupy the void between the neighboring sheets and maintains no remarkable weak interactions (such as Ag···Nacetonitrile and Cacetonitrile−H···π interactions) with the 2D sheet.
elements.clean_text: The most fascinating feature of 1 is the presence of a square cavity which is comprised of four bulging phenyl rings as wall, four inverse-arranged phenyl rings as supports, and four Ag2 ions as bottom. The overall shape of this cavity is reminiscent of a flowerpot where one of two acetonitrile molecules is suspended and interacts with four symmetry-related basal Ag2 ions (Figure a and b). The acetonitrile N atom points downward toward the center of the bottom, consistent with the formation of a Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile interaction. The Ag2⋅⋅⋅N1 distance is 2.824(6) Å, which is a little longer but still falls in the secondary bonding range (the sum of van der Waals radii of Ag and N is 3.27 Å) and is comparable to other reported Ag⋅⋅⋅acetonitrile weak coordination interactions. The entrapped acetonitrile molecules in the holes of the 2D sheet are alternately arranged as shown in Figure b. Another acetonitrile molecule just acts as guest to occupy the void between the neighboring sheets and maintains no remarkable weak interactions (such as Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile and Cacetonitrile-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions) with the 2D sheet.

elements.content: As we know, Yaghi and co-workers utilized a bowl-shaped inorganic [V12O32]4− to obtain the first acetonitrile and benzonitrile inclusion complexes, [CH3CN⊂V12O32]4− and [C6H5CN⊂V12O32]4−, respectively. The driving force to entrap these neutral molecules in [V12O32]4− is mainly originated from the V···N noncovalent interactions. After the careful comparison, we found that the N atom of the acetonitrile molecule in 1 is only 1.44 Å away from the plane defined by four symmetry-related basal Ag2 ions, but the N atom of acetonitrile in [CH3CN⊂V12O32]4− lies 2.22 Å above the bottom of the [V12O32]4− and the benzonitrile molecule in [C6H5CN⊂V12O32]4− locates itself much further away from the bottom of the bowl. The distinct penetration depth of the guest molecules reflects that their binding behaviors significantly depend on the inbeing (e.g. geometry and interior environment) of the host as well as the shape and size of themselves.
elements.clean_text: As we know, Yaghi and co-workers utilized a bowl-shaped inorganic [V12O32]4- to obtain the first acetonitrile and benzonitrile inclusion complexes, [CH3CN⊂V12O32]4- and [C6H5CN⊂V12O32]4-, respectively. The driving force to entrap these neutral molecules in [V12O32]4- is mainly originated from the V⋅⋅⋅N noncovalent interactions. After the careful comparison, we found that the N atom of the acetonitrile molecule in 1 is only 1.44 Å away from the plane defined by four symmetry-related basal Ag2 ions, but the N atom of acetonitrile in [CH3CN⊂V12O32]4- lies 2.22 Å above the bottom of the [V12O32]4- and the benzonitrile molecule in [C6H5CN⊂V12O32]4- locates itself much further away from the bottom of the bowl. The distinct penetration depth of the guest molecules reflects that their binding behaviors significantly depend on the inbeing (e.g. geometry and interior environment) of the host as well as the shape and size of themselves.

(b) The 2D sheet structure incorporating the Ag···Ag interaction is highlighted by cyan lines. (Symmetry codes: (ii) −x + 1, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; (iii) −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2; (iv) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 1.)

elements.content: Using the non-acetonitrile solvent (H2O) in the same preparative procedure, a new 2D sheet silver(I) phthalate CP 2, {[Ag2(pta)(H2O)]} n , was isolated. This result suggests that complex 1 cannot form in the absence of acetonitrile, proving the template effect of acetonitrile in the formation of 1. Complex 2 is insoluble in common solvents, so it cannot transform into complex 1 when immersed in acetonitrile. Although complex 2 has the same metal and ligand ratio with 1, the 2D sheet in 2 is obviously distinct from that in 1 and does not include any solvent-occupied cavity. In 2, two crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions adopt T-shaped and distorted trigonal−bipyramidal geometries (τ5 = 0.603, for ideal trigonal−bipyramidal geometry, τ5 = 1), respectively (Figure a). The water molecule just monodentately coordinates with Ag(I) without an obvious template effect. The Ag···Ag contacts in 2 range from 3.0912(9) to 3.2609(8) Å. The pta ligand shows a μ6-η2:η2:η2:η1 coordination mode extending the Ag(I) ions into the 2D sheet structure (Figure b). The structural contrasts between 1 and 2 are undoubtedly associated with the solvent-dependent inclusion.
elements.clean_text: Using the non-acetonitrile solvent (H2O) in the same preparative procedure, a new 2D sheet silver(I) phthalate CP 2, {[Ag2(pta)(H2O)]} n , was isolated. This result suggests that complex 1 cannot form in the absence of acetonitrile, proving the template effect of acetonitrile in the formation of 1. Complex 2 is insoluble in common solvents, so it cannot transform into complex 1 when immersed in acetonitrile. Although complex 2 has the same metal and ligand ratio with 1, the 2D sheet in 2 is obviously distinct from that in 1 and does not include any solvent-occupied cavity. In 2, two crystallographically independent Ag(I) ions adopt T-shaped and distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometries (τ5 = 0.603, for ideal trigonal-bipyramidal geometry, τ5 = 1), respectively (Figure a). The water molecule just monodentately coordinates with Ag(I) without an obvious template effect. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts in 2 range from 3.0912(9) to 3.2609(8) Å. The pta ligand shows a μ6-η2:η2:η2:η1 coordination mode extending the Ag(I) ions into the 2D sheet structure (Figure b). The structural contrasts between 1 and 2 are undoubtedly associated with the solvent-dependent inclusion.

elements.content: Photoluminescence of complexes 1 and 2 in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: 4  Photoluminescence of complexes 1 and 2 in the solid state.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for complexes 1 and 2 was measured under N2 atmosphere. The TGA curve () of 1 shows that the first weight loss takes place at 120−190 °C and corresponds to the loss of two acetonitrile molecules (obsd: 4.84% and calcd: 5.13%). From then on, almost no weight loss is observed until 255 °C, at which temperature it starts to decompose along with the loss of pta ligand (obsd: 40.11% and calcd: 40.34%). For 2, the coordinated water molecule loss occurs from 140 to 170 °C (obsd: 3.55% and calcd: 4.52%) and then the sheet starts to decompose at around 171 °C along with the loss of pta (obsd: 39.81% and calcd: 41.25%). The acetonitrile and water molecules are lost at relatively high temperature, which confirms that they have relatively strong interaction with the sheets, as observed in the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis.
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for complexes 1 and 2 was measured under N2 atmosphere. The TGA curve () of 1 shows that the first weight loss takes place at 120-190 °C and corresponds to the loss of two acetonitrile molecules (obsd: 4.84% and calcd: 5.13%). From then on, almost no weight loss is observed until 255 °C, at which temperature it starts to decompose along with the loss of pta ligand (obsd: 40.11% and calcd: 40.34%). For 2, the coordinated water molecule loss occurs from 140 to 170 °C (obsd: 3.55% and calcd: 4.52%) and then the sheet starts to decompose at around 171 °C along with the loss of pta (obsd: 39.81% and calcd: 41.25%). The acetonitrile and water molecules are lost at relatively high temperature, which confirms that they have relatively strong interaction with the sheets, as observed in the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis.

elements.content: The solvent removal of 1 can be easily realized by heating the as-synthesized sample of 1 at 190 °C for 5 h according to the TGA curve. The resulting desolvated 1 shows a different XRD pattern with both 1 and 2 (), suggesting the formation of an unknown substance. When the desolvated 1 is immersed in the acetonitrile overnight and then air-dried, the XRD pattern of it is still identical to that of desolvated 1. Therefore, the reversible removal and inclusion of acetonitrile in 1 can be ruled out.
elements.clean_text: The solvent removal of 1 can be easily realized by heating the as-synthesized sample of 1 at 190 °C for 5 h according to the TGA curve. The resulting desolvated 1 shows a different XRD pattern with both 1 and 2 (), suggesting the formation of an unknown substance. When the desolvated 1 is immersed in the acetonitrile overnight and then air-dried, the XRD pattern of it is still identical to that of desolvated 1. Therefore, the reversible removal and inclusion of acetonitrile in 1 can be ruled out.

elements.content: The photoluminescence spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , excitation of solid samples of 1 and 2 at 360 nm produces emissions with maxima at approximately 478 and 460 nm, respectively. Compared to the photoluminescence spectrum of the free H2pta ligand (λem = 345 nm), the emission bands of both 1 and 2 are red-shifted by more than 100 nm. Specifically, emission of 1 occurs at a lower energy than that of 2, which can be partially explained by the existence of a shorter Ag···Ag distance (2.8082(5) Å) in 1 and, hence, a stronger Ag···Ag interaction, which has an important influence on the photoluminescence properties of this kind of complexes. The emitting states of 1 and 2 can be tentatively assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) mainly arising from Ag(I)→pta, mixed with metal-centered (d−s/d−p) transitions. Additionally, the distinct emission behaviors also to some extent involved the different coordination mode and arrangement of ligand in the coordination network.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminescence spectra of 1 and 2 were measured in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , excitation of solid samples of 1 and 2 at 360 nm produces emissions with maxima at approximately 478 and 460 nm, respectively. Compared to the photoluminescence spectrum of the free H2pta ligand (λem = 345 nm), the emission bands of both 1 and 2 are red-shifted by more than 100 nm. Specifically, emission of 1 occurs at a lower energy than that of 2, which can be partially explained by the existence of a shorter Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance (2.8082(5) Å) in 1 and, hence, a stronger Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction, which has an important influence on the photoluminescence properties of this kind of complexes. The emitting states of 1 and 2 can be tentatively assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) mainly arising from Ag(I)→pta, mixed with metal-centered (d-s/d-p) transitions. Additionally, the distinct emission behaviors also to some extent involved the different coordination mode and arrangement of ligand in the coordination network.

elements.content: In summary, the results show the important templating role that acetonitrile can play in the formation of a 2D sheet involving the quadruplex Ag···Nacetonitrile interaction. Moreover, the distinct emission behaviors of 1 and 2 also were discussed.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the results show the important templating role that acetonitrile can play in the formation of a 2D sheet involving the quadruplex Ag⋅⋅⋅Nacetonitrile interaction. Moreover, the distinct emission behaviors of 1 and 2 also were discussed.

elements.content: Syntheses of complexes 1 and 2, selected bond lengths and angles, simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns, IR and TGA curve, and X-ray crystallographic files in cif format for complexes 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Syntheses of complexes 1 and 2, selected bond lengths and angles, simulated and experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns, IR and TGA curve, and X-ray crystallographic files in cif format for complexes 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The TGA curve () of 1 shows that the first weight loss takes place at 120−190 °C and corresponds to the loss of two acetonitrile molecules (obsd: 4.84% and calcd: 5.13%). From then on, almost no weight loss is observed until 255 °C, at which temperature it starts to decompose along with the loss of pta ligand (obsd: 40.11% and calcd: 40.34%). For 2, the coordinated water molecule loss occurs from 140 to 170 °C (obsd: 3.55% and calcd: 4.52%) and then the sheet starts to decompose at around 171 °C along with the loss of pta (obsd: 39.81% and calcd: 41.25%). The acetonitrile and water molecules are lost at relatively high temperature, which confirms that they have relatively strong interaction with the sheets, as observed in the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis.
